title: Harmless and ecologically acceptable fabrication of long-acting injectable microspheres.
reasoning: The abstract discusses the use of non-halogenated solvents as alternatives to methylene chloride in the fabrication of PLA and PLGA microspheres, highlighting advantages related to environment and worker safety. title: NOVEL ECOFRIENDLY TECHNIQUE FOR SPECTROPHOTOMETRIC ANALYSIS OF DICLOFENAC SODIUM TABLETS USING MELTED N, N- DIMETHYLUREA AS SOLID SOLVENT
reasoning: The abstract proposes using aqueous solutions of N, N-dimethylurea as a hydrotropic agent to replace organic solvents including methylene chloride for spectrophotometric analysis. It explicitly states that the new method is ecofriendly and free from toxicity of organic solvents, indicating a safety advantage over methylene chloride.

target_chemical_harm.rationale: The reasoning text explicitly states that organic solvents, including methylene chloride, have drawbacks such as toxicity and pollution.

title: Removing Acrylic Conformal Coating with Safer Solvents for Re-Manufacturing Electronics
reasoning: The abstract explicitly states that the research identified safer solvent blends as alternatives to Methylene Chloride (DCM) for acrylic conformal coating stripping. It highlights that these alternatives provide equivalent stripping performance with improved safety and toxicity profiles, indicating a safer alternative to DCM.

title: Improved and Novel Methods for Investigating Organophosphate Esters in Particulate Matter

title: Conventional versus novel extraction techniques for wheat germ oil recovery: multi-response optimization of supercritical fluid extraction
reasoning: The abstract compares conventional Soxhlet extraction using methylene chloride with novel techniques including supercritical fluid extraction (SFE). It states that SFE provides advantages such as absence of organic solvent residues and similar or higher antioxidant activity, implying a safety benefit over methylene chloride use. Therefore, SFE is presented as a safer alternative to methylene chloride.
